Future work recommended by (and inferred from) the text includes:

• Improved Coupling of Models: Combine groundwater models (e.g., MODFLOW) with high-temporal-resolution crop (DSSAT) or vadose zone (HYDRUS 1D, SWAT-HYDRUS) simulators to better capture daily evapotranspiration, irrigation demands, and episodic recharge events.

• Refined Recharge Estimates: Develop more detailed recharge projections to account for uncertainty in global climate models. This involves careful attention to precipitation timing, as well as inclusion of downscaled climate data to improve forward-looking water resource planning.

• High-Resolution Time-Stepping: Recognize that both irrigation requirements and recharge can be highly sensitive to the timing of rainfall, necessitating daily or similarly fine time-step simulations rather than monthly or annual averaging.

• Better Calibration and Data Collection: Seek more direct measurements (e.g., metered pumping, in-field crop water use) to reduce uncertainties. Future studies should incorporate newly available data to refine parameterization and validate model outputs under different climate and pumping scenarios.

• Long-Term Scenario Analyses: Expand multi-decadal and century-scale modeling efforts to evaluate climate-driven changes in aquifer storage and recharge, especially under a range of emission scenarios and variable rainfall patterns.

Based on the report sections provided, the main recommendations for future work focus on continued water‐level monitoring and data refinement:

• Annual Water‐Level Measurements. The authors identify a specific set of wells (shown in Figure 14 and listed in Table 3) to be measured yearly. These wells were chosen for their spacing relative to the water‐level variogram range (about 9,000 feet in the 135° direction) to give good spatial coverage and capture how water levels may recover or flatten over time.

• Focus on Key Monitoring Sites. All wells on the Wall property currently measured yearly by the OLWC should continue to be monitored, complemented by the twelve additional wells successfully measured in January 2023. By keeping consistent, long‐term data from these specific wells, changes in cones of depression and overall trends in water‐level elevation can be tracked accurately.

• Refinement of Geostatistical Models. As new data are collected, the geostatistical interpolations (variograms and trends) can be updated. This is particularly important in the outer areas where current data are sparse and uncertainty is high; additional measurements would help reduce uncertainty and improve the reliability of aquifer‐storage estimates.

• Verification of Storage Estimates. Monitoring data should be periodically used to compare actual water‐level trends against the interpolations, especially beyond the variogram range buffer. The report cautions that areas lying outside this range are driven mostly by the trend surface model, so additional sampling or drilling in these zones could improve the confidence in storage estimates.

Overall, the authors stress the importance of measuring these recommended wells yearly, refining spatial models as new measurements become available, and treating all storage estimates outside the core (well‐supported) areas with appropriate caution until more data are gathered.
